title: So I decided to try being a "never surrender" asshole for a while.
body: Guess what. Doesn't make a difference. I still don't get why people watch a 4-22 at 15 minutes game and say shit like "it's winnable". The outcome wasn't different from what I expected. You can't just will a win from an obvious loss. That's not how reality works. No amount of wishing I was a bird will make me one in reality. I can wish to be a billionaire with a 9 inch member all I want, I won't become that. I can pretend that I have psychic powers all day, I will never move a table with my mind. Why would anyone think it would work any differently here?  Now I'm even more devout in my believe that lost games should be surrendered early. FF@154Lyfe homie!!!

replies.body:
FF15 has a 100% loss rate. Games in which people try to make a comeback do not.

If everyone is up for surrender, FF15 makes sense. Getting tilted because someone else isn't ready to give up only implies that you think your opinion matters 100% more than theirs does, and still guarantees a loss (your weak mental tilts them as well) - only you have to wait an extra 5-15 minutes for it. If you're going to be stuck in the game anyways, why not try to pull off an epic comeback?

thats obviously a true statement but if i think about it...
id rather take that 100% loss rate over a 95% lossrate where the 5% wins we had were such a pain to full off and took us 40+ min... 
nah not worth.

40+ minute games where we come back to win are the most fun games I have. Some people love the 20 minute games where victory was never in doubt, but if it weren't for those epic comeback games I'm not sure I'd enjoy League as much as I do.

There is no “playing from behind” anymore. As soon as you’re behind you’ve lost the game.

> It's shitshow, as always, throws occur everywhere, very often...

You really think anyone is stupid enough to throw a 4-25 at 15 minutes kind of lead? I've only seen this once in nearly 1000 ranked games I played last season.

I've won a number of 4v5s last season. In fact, when I got my main account to Gold for the first time last season, I had to hard carry two 4v5s along the way. One of them was a 4v5 from about 1 minute and some seconds into the match. Thing is, in those matches my team was clearly better. I've learned that a 4v5 is just as winnable as a 5v5. The only thing that really matters is which team has the hardcore feeding shits. 

Any game that's a come back or a win from a seemingly huge disadvantage was never actually hopeless. If you team isn't mentally defective then there is very little chance you'd lose. But if a game starts off with your team just inting it up, then it's pretty clear which team has the shit players. There is no point in playing those out. The vast majority of the time it's very easy to tell that you have a team of down syndrome sub-human trash. They are not going to stop being trash later in the game. Why waste the time?

I've came back and won from having all of my towers destroyed and inhibs down. Most of the time I don't give up unless I cannot see a way for our team to pull through and come back from being so far behind.

This kind of thing is exceedingly rare. Too rare to make any difference in the long run. If it wasn't then the concept of being "hard stuck" wouldn't be such a popular sentiment. The "never ff" crowd vastly outnumbers the "ff@15" crowd, yet so many people complain about being hard stuck. There are dozens of threads on these very boards where people complain about match making, feeders, trolls etc. I'm willing to wager that a vast majority of these people don't like to surrender obviously lost ranked games. So why are these people still losing games? Why are they still not climbing? Clearly never surrendering isn't working for them.

Actually, the first step to activating psychic powers is acknowledging that they absolutely do exist.  Jest thee may, but simply being aware the topic exists due to popular cultural references instead of learned through a process of isolation and self-discovery is your greatest barrier to entry.  Remember, the total amount of human comprehension about the nature of reality comprises only the tiniest fraction of it's actual, greater sum.
